hints_html: Try making a sketch of the region of integration first, rather than trying to tackle this problem from a purely algebraic standpoint.
hints_latex:
Try making a sketch of the region of integration first, rather than
trying to tackle this problem from a purely algebraic standpoint.
hints_raw: Try making a sketch of the region of integration first, rather than trying to tackle this problem from a purely algebraic standpoint.
question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
If we examine the region of integration by drawing a picture...

... we see that if we integrate with respect to y first, that we can specify the lower bound of integration as \(y = x^{2}\) and the upper bound as \(y = x + 2\). Looking at where the lines meet, we can see that the bounds of integration for x is x = -1 to x = 2. (To find these intersection points solve the equation \(x^{2} = x + 2\).)

From these observations, we can write I as follows

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}I = \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}f(x,y)\,\textrm{d}y\textrm{d}x }\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
If we examine the region of integration by drawing a picture...

[[File:MATH200 Dec2012 Q6a.png|center|frame|The domain of integration is enclosed within the curves <math>\displaystyle x = y - 2</math> (black), <math>{\color{blue}x = -\sqrt{y}}</math> (blue), and <math>{\color{red}x = \sqrt{y}}</math> (red)]]

... we see that if we integrate with respect to <i>y</i> first, that we can specify the lower bound of integration as <math>y = x^{2}</math> and the upper bound as <math>y = x + 2</math>. Looking at where the lines meet, we can see that the bounds of integration for <i>x</i> is <i>x = -1</i> to <i>x = 2</i>. (To find these intersection points solve the equation <math>x^{2} = x + 2</math>.)

From these observations, we can write <i>I</i> as follows:  <math>
{\color{blue}
I = \int_{-1}^{2}\int_{x^{2}}^{x + 2}f(x,y)\,\textrm{d}y\textrm{d}x
}
</math>
statement_html:
Combine the sum of the iterated integrals

\[\begin{aligned} I=\int_0^1\int_{-\sqrt{y}}^{\sqrt{y}}f(x,y)\textrm{d}x\textrm{d}y+\int_1^4\int_{y-2}^{\sqrt{y}}f(x,y)\textrm{d}x\textrm{d}y\end{aligned}\]

into a single iterated integral with the order of integration reversed.
statement_raw:
Combine the sum of the iterated integrals

:<math>
I=\int_0^1\int_{-\sqrt{y}}^{\sqrt{y}}f(x,y)\textrm{d}x\textrm{d}y+\int_1^4\int_{y-2}^{\sqrt{y}}f(x,y)\textrm{d}x\textrm{d}y
</math>

into a single iterated integral with the order of integration reversed.
